Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Automated Building Scale Urine Treatment System
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project lies in transforming a source of water pollution into a renewable source of fertilizer, which will reduce dependence on non-renewable resources for both wastewater treatment and fertilizer production. Rather than combining all domestic wastewater into one dilute stream, this project inverts the paradigm by separating out and recycling the largest source of nutrient pollution: urine. Special toilets with a separate drain at the front of the bowl direct urine through dedicated plumbing to a compact building-scale processor, which converts it into a purified liquid fertilizer. This technology will have immediate utility in sensitive watersheds where regulations require landowners to remove nitrogen from wastewater using expensive septic systems upgrades. Urine diversion could be an alternative to such upgrades, at a lower cost, with less ongoing energy demand, and with the added benefit of producing fertilizer as an end product. When the technology is more mature, it could be applied in areas served by central sewers, as a decentralized nutrient recovery strategy. The technology will create jobs in installation and service, reduce the load on wastewater treatment plants, help restore our waterways, and yield a clean, domestically-produced fertilizer for use in agriculture.<br/><br/>This SBIR Phase I project will advance translation of a building-scale urine collection and treatment system is paired with commercially-available urine-diverting toilet fixtures to create an advanced resource recovery system with a conventional bathroom experience. The system employs a four-step process: acidification, pasteurization, freeze concentration, and charcoal filtration. The combined effect of these four steps includes volume reduction, odor control, nutrient stabilization, and removal of contaminants such as pathogens and pharmaceutical residues. The project has two main goals: 1) measuring the energy requirements of the treatment steps, using these data to optimize the freeze concentration step; and 2) testing the performance during ongoing operation to identify and address problems relating to biofilm or mineral scale formation. The proposed freeze concentrator uses a proprietary technology that is mechanically simple, energy-efficient, and scalable to a small physical footprint. In addition to urine diversion, this device could have useful applications in other fields requiring a small, mechanically simple, and inexpensive dewatering system. The four processing subsystems will be designed using thermal and hydraulic modeling, and tested using real urine from a source-separating toilet. Subsystems will be tested individually for performance and energy efficiency, and then together as an integrated system.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phase I Project Outcomes Report


The objective of this project was to develop a building-scale system for creating fertilizer out of urine and ultra-low-flush toilet waste. The process involves multiple steps, and produces a sanitized and concentrated fertilizer product.   


The US and many other parts of the world are currently facing the impacts of severe drought. Toilets are the largest single user of indoor water in the home, and in office buildings it is even more extreme, with restrooms accounting for 37% of all indoor and outdoor water usage. Our product helps slash bathroom water use in office buildings and facilitate onsite water reuse, while also addressing two other pressing environmental problems: nutrient pollution and synthetic fertilizer production.


According to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, ?Nutrient pollution is one of America's most widespread, costly, and challenging environmental problems, and is caused by excess nitrogen and phosphorus in the air and water.? Wastewater is one of the major contributors to nutrient pollution, though the exact fraction varies by land use and population in each watershed. Within wastewater, the majority of nutrients (80% of N and 50% of P) come from urine, even though urine makes up less than 1% of wastewater volume.


Additionally, nitrogen and phosphorus are essential to global food production, and each have associated risks and challenges. Phosphorus is a non-renewable mined resource, and remaining global reserves of phosphorus are decreasing in quality and accessibility at the same time that global demand is increasing. Nitrogen is abundant in the atmosphere, but the industrial process for fixing nitrogen into fertilizer is energy intensive, requiring 1.1% of total global energy use. By extracting fertilizer from wastewater, we can reduce our dependence.


A promising strategy to help with all these issues begins with using waterless urinals and ultra low-flush vacuum-flush toilets to minimize water usage and to concentrate all human waste into a high-strength, high-nutrient substream. Our device then extracts the plant nutrients from this high-strength stream, producing natural fertilizer that can be used as a replacement for synthetic fertilizer. Another benefit of recovering these nutrients is that it reduces the strength of the remaining wastewater, making it easier to treat onsite for non-potable reuse applications like irrigation.


During our SBIR Phase I project, Rich Earth LLC has developed the three main components of a

building-scale urine/digested blackwater collection and treatment system. These components

include:


  1. Acid stabilization of urine in waterless urinals to prevent mineral scale and clogged pipes
  2. Freeze concentration of source-separated urine or digested blackwater to create a concentrated fertilizer
  3. Pasteurization of the fertilizer product to destroy pathogens and comply with regulations.

During Phase I, we achieved significant de-risking in each of the three primary system components:


Acidification: we showed that citric acid can be dosed with each toilet use to successfully prevent pipe clogging and even remove existing mineral scale.


Freeze concentration component: we demonstrated the efficacy of block freeze concentration as a

method to produce a >5X concentrate and retain >90% of the nutrients. We also demonstrated the

concept of using latent heat recovery to increase the energy efficiency of the freeze concentration

Process. This work is detailed in a paper published in ACS Engineering ?Advancing the Design and Operating Conditions for Block Freeze Concentration of Urine-Derived Fertilizer? (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsestengg.1c00271)


Pasteurization: we achieved the goal of creating a simple (few moving parts) and efficient (15.28 Wh/L) single-flow countercurrent heat exchanger that pasteurizes the final product of the entire system.


We hope that this work will help strengthen the position of the US in the field of productive sanitation, facilitating the  development of a nutrient recovery system that is more affordable, less physically disruptive, and more  energy efficient than existing wastewater options, leading to cleaner rivers and more sustainable farms. Our building-scale treatment system has the potential to enable water conservation and reuse, prevent nutrient pollution, and produce a local, sustainable fertilizer source. Each of these impacts intersect with the broader goals of climate resilience, as the sustainability of water and nutrient resource management all depend on solutions that can both mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the changing climate.
